item.title: Guardian Cities in Mumbai – day one
item.description:
The Guardian Cities team is in Mumbai this week, exploring every aspect of the city in association with NDTV.com. Follow this live blog for the latest stories, films and at 1.30pm GMT / 7pm IST, a live-streamed debate on what life is like for women in Mumbai

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Mike Herd ,Saptarshi Ray ,Chris Michael, and Francesca Perry in Mumbai

item.title: Obama to shield 5m migrants from deportation – a look at the numbers
item.description:
President Obama is expected to announce new measures to safeguard 5m migrants from the threat of deportation. We look at the numbers behind the likely proposals, and how they affect each state differently

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli and George Arnett

item.title: Religious extremism main cause of terrorism, according to report
item.description:
Since 2001 religious extremism has overtaken national separatism to become the main driver of terrorist attacks around the world, according to the Global Terrorism Index

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: George Arnett

item.title: Can it pass the Senate? Interactive Australian voting calculator
item.description:
As senator Jacqui Lambie has resigned from the Palmer United Party to become an independent, the Senate has become even more unpredictable. This voting calculator allows you to test and share different voting combinations to see how and if a bill could be passed. The calculator assumes all senators will be present, and so a majority of 39 is needed to pass legislation, and 38 are needed to block.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Nick Evershed

item.title: Renewable energy v fossil fuel: how the states stack up
item.description:
Climate Council report ranks Australian states by their emissions, renewable energy production, and investment

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Nick Evershed

item.title: Over 90% of drowning deaths happen in lower and middle income countries
item.description:
Around 372,000 people a year die through drowning with the vast bulk of those occurring in the world’s poorer countries

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: George Arnett

item.title: Opium harvest in Afghanistan reaches record levels after troop withdrawal
item.description:
The cultivation of poppies for opium gains more ground, with Helmand province - which British troops pulled out of this year - remaining the region producing the most

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: George Arnett

item.title: How the G20 subsidises exploration for fossil fuel – interactive
item.description:
Governments from G20 countries are spending $88bn (£55.4bn) to subsidise the search for new oil, gas and coal reserves – more than double the amount being spent by the top 20 private oil and gas companies. The UK, for example, is spending $664m for exploration in Russia, Brazil, India and Ghana among other nations, according to the Overseas Development Institute and Oil Change International who gathered the data. Click on the buttons below to see where 10 selected countries are directing their funds in the search for fossil fuels

Read: rich countries subsidising oil, gas and coal companies by $88bn a year

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Paddy Allen

item.title: Victoria reimagined: see the state resized by the statistics that matter
item.description:
This interactive cartogram allows you to resize electorates by statistics from the 2011 census and the outcome of the 2010 Victorian election. You can, for example, resize by population to see all the smaller, metropolitan electorates on the same scale as the larger regional divisions. You can also re-colour electorates by each statistic to view trends across two indicators at once.

There are 88 seats in the legislative assembly. Currently the Coalition has 44, Labor 43, and there is one independent. After the redistribution of boundaries, Labor requires a 0.9% statewide swing to win. The census stats and 2010 margins have been adjusted for the new electoral boundaries.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Nick Evershed

item.title: The legalisation of marijuana isn't just about liberal values - it's about dollars
item.description:
The tax revenues from marijuana in states where it has been legalised are relatively sizeable - is this one of the reasons why many places are consenting to pro-marijuana legislation?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David McCandless and Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Political dynasties keep winning, and six other things to know from the midterms
item.description:
However the numbers are sliced and diced, the result was a GOP landslide, but how far this wave will actually carry the Republicans remains unknown

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

item.title: World’s top companies fall short on transparency
item.description:
The world’s biggest companies disclose little or no financial details about their operations outside their home countries, Transparency International says

item.dc:creator: Clar Ni Chonghaile and Ami Sedghi

item.title: Which sport is Australia’s most dangerous?
item.description:
The findings of a new report on sporting injuries are both surprising (who would have thought golf is a hidden killer?) and expected (stay away from quadbikes), but how do the major codes stack up?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Nick Evershed

item.title: European countries dominate in global prosperity rankings
item.description:
Norway has been named the most prosperous country in the world for the sixth year in a row and European countries dominate the top 30 of the annual Prosperity Index

item.description:
From the most popular Halloween fancy dress choices in the UK to the amount expected to be spent on festivities - here is everything you wanted to know about Halloween, in numbers

item.title: Quiz: how well do you know Australia?
item.description:
A new report shows that most people are very wrong on some of the key facts about their home nation. See if you know any better with this quiz from Ipsos Mori.

• Read more about the survey here

item.description:
The UK falls eight places in rankings measuring gender equality worldwide, with Nordic countries such as Iceland and Sweden continuing to come out on top

item.title: Where on earth is the Berlin wall?
item.description:
Twenty five years after its fall, more pieces of the Berlin wall are scattered across the globe – from Seattle to South Korea, Cape Town to Canberra – than remain in the city itself

item.title: There is bipartisan agreement on one thing: Obama's immigration action is controversial
item.description:

item.title: Tony Abbott keeps digging himself in deeper, and it makes no sense
item.description:
The Abbott government is in untenable positions on climate change and broken election promises and it’s time it took stock

item.title: The artful dodger: Iranian tarof and nuclear negotiations
item.description:
Adam Cameron says the cultural practice of tarof doesn’t mean Iranians are devious – either in daily life or in the nuclear negotiations

item.title: Australia is blocking refugees registered in Indonesia. What will happen now?
item.description:
The Australian government says its rule changes will stop asylum seekers travelling to Indonesia and risking their lives at sea, but will it work? And what does it mean for those already there?

Jerusalem synagogue attack: live updates Continue reading...

item.title: Japan's election won't just be a referendum on Abenomics
item.description:
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has announced a snap election for December. The vote is being branded as a referendum on the PM’s economic plans, but with debates on defence and nuclear energy still dividing public opinion the balance of power that emerges from the ballot box will matter greatly

  • Japan calls snap election
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Iran nuclear talks – the Guardian briefing
item.description:
Iran and a six-nation negotiating group are trying to reach an agreement that could bring an end to 12 years of deadlock over Iran’s nuclear programme. Read a brief history of the standoff and find out why the outcome of the talks is still in the balance

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Julian Borger and Saeed Kamali Dehghan

item.title: Johannesburg's art scene is thriving, but at what price?

item.title: Philip Nitschke tribunal: a clinical, jarring discussion on rational suicide
item.description:
The impact on family or friends was rarely mentioned in a three-day hearing on whether the euthanasia campaigner can keep his licence. So what has been learned about the right to die?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Helen Davidson in Darwin

item.title: Can the Victorian Greens wield any real power beyond persuasion?
item.description:
The Greens hope to win the balance of power in both houses of parliament. But they’ve talked up their chances before, and they don’t yet have a Bob Brown to give them a compelling presence

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Gay Alcorn

item.title: Islamic State boasts influx of foreign recruits in latest beheadings video
item.description:
Procession of foreign-looking recruits featured in new video, which counter-terrorism experts say portray group as being at the forefront of global jihad

  • Experts try to identify foreign jihadis in Isis video

item.title: Victorian election preferences: perversity rules battle for upper house
item.description:
The struggle between purity and pragmatism in preference swaps means voters may wake up with a Senate-style surprise

item.title: Latest Islamic State horror masks a week of defeats
item.description: Gruesome videos are taking a toll on populations in Iraq and Syria that are increasingly captive to power of Isis propaganda Continue reading...

item.title: G20: Barack Obama leaves his woes at home as he woos young Australia
item.description:

item.title: Across Europe disillusioned voters turn to outsiders for solutions
item.description:
Our correspondents in the European capitals report on the rise of insurgent parties across the continent

item.title: Green Climate Fund: five key facts
item.description:
Developing countries see fund as help for countries that did the least to cause climate change and are likely to suffer most

G20 Brisbane: follow our live coverage

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Goldenberg

item.title: Scott Ludlam: ABC cuts ‘a disastrous decision’ – video
item.description: Senator Scott Ludlam says the Greens will be at the forefront of the effort to have funding returned to the ABC and SBS. Ludlam accused the Coalition government of 'taking its marching orders from the unelected policy geniuses at the Institute of Public Affairs' which has the dismantling and selling off of the public broadcasters as its policy. Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: The changing face of homelessness in Victoria - audio slideshow
item.description: There are an estimated 22,000 homeless people in Victoria, but the traditional homeless avatar of the grizzled older man on a park bench is increasingly misleading. Half are now under 25 and 3,000 of them children and soaring rents, domestic violence and mental health issues mean are increasingly to blame Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Oliver Milman and Meredith O'Shea

item.title: Jacqui Lambie announces resignation from Palmer United party - video
item.description: Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie announces she will quit the Palmer United party and continue in the Senate as an independent. Lambie says she will focus on negotiating on behalf of Tasmanians and will not support the government's agenda on higher education or the proposed Medicare co-payment. She calls on the prime minister to reverse his position on defence pay Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Newborn baby found in Sydney drain – video
item.description: A woman has been charged with attempted murder following the discovery of a newborn baby boy in a drain in Sydney's west. The baby was rescued, wrapped in a hospital blanket, from the bottom of a drain after a cyclist heard him crying while passing by in Quakers Hill. Bystanders helped to lift the concrete slab covering the drain to allow police to go down to rescue the baby. He was taken to Westmead Children's hospital in a serious but stable condition. Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Aftermath of 6.8-magnitude earthquake in central Japan - video
item.description: Residents of Hakuba, Japan, begin a clear-up on Sunday after a 6.8-magnitude rocked the area late on Saturday. No fatalities have been reported but at least 39 people were injured in the quake, with seven severely hurt. No tsunami warning has been issued since the earthquake Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: The top 20 moments that shaped the world - in pictures
item.description:
The British Council has produced a new list of the top 80 moments and trends across global politics, culture, science and education, that reflects the view of between 749 and 1,249 adults aged 18 to 65 with a minimum level of secondary education in Brazil, China, Egypt, Germany, India, Japan, Russia, South Africa, the UK and US. The polling was conducted by YouGov

80 landmarks in 80 years: the people and events that shaped our world

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Josy Forsdike

item.title: Obama runs back to the White House before Las Vegas trip – because he forgot his BlackBerry
item.description:
Fresh off his evening’s speech on immigration, Barack Obama headed to Las Vegas on Friday morning to speak in front of a campaign-like crowd to mark his policy changes. The morning was not without its hiccups, as the president departed, then returned, then departed again

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Pirate Joe's, the Vancouver store that resells Trader Joe's goods – in pictures
item.description:
Michael Hallatt has run Pirate Joe’s for three years now, bringing Trader Joe’s goods across the border to be resold to visitors to his Vancouver storefront. Here, a look inside the legal operation

  • Meet Pirate Joe, the man who (legally) smuggles Trader Joe’s goods into Canada
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Mexico: protesters clash with police over missing student teachers – in pictures
item.description:
Demonstrators marched in the biggest protest so far to pressure the government into finding the 43 missing student teachers who disappeared seven weeks ago

  • Mexico on the brink: thousands to protest over widespread corruption and student massacre
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Joanna Ruck

item.title: Protesters clash with police in Mexico City over missing students - video
item.description: Protesters throw rocks, fireworks and petrol bombs at police in Mexico City during a large demonstration, following the disappearance of 43 students. The clashes on Thursday night, in the city's central Zócalo plaza, threatened to overshadow an overwhelmingly peaceful march in the city, in which tens of thousands of people attended Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Watching Obama's immigration speech with a family of Bolivian migrants – video
item.description: In Arlington, Virginia friends and members of the Andrade family gathered to watch Obama's speech. Some family members present were undocumented migrants. Some are eligible to receive protection from deportation under the new actions announced on Thursday night. Some are not. Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Dan Roberts

item.title: Astrid Silva: Obama's immigration action 'changes everything' – video
item.description: Astrid Silva, the young woman mentioned in Obama's landmark immigration speech, was brought to the United States when she was four years old. She speaks to the Guardian's Rory Carroll about what the president's executive actions mean for her family: 'Just to know that they are going to be OK ... I don't have to be scared that they're going to get deported.' Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Rory Carroll in Los Angeles

item.title: Obama eases threat of deportation for millions of undocumented migrants - video
item.description: President Barack Obama promised to ease the threat of deportation for about 4.7 million undocumented migrants, bypassing Congress and angering Republicans. Obama announced a three-part plan which involves providing additional resources for border patrol security, in order to stem the flow of illegal crossings. The president also said he will use his executive authority to allow undocumented residents to legally apply for jobs and join American society, but without any guarantee of permanent residency or citizenship Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Funeral held for murdered Miss Honduras and sister - video
item.description: The funeral for Maria Jose Alvadaro and her sister Sofia is held in Honduras on Thursday, amid grief-stricken family and friends. The pair's sister, Corina Alvarado, says they were always 'honest, happy and sincere'. Two men have been arrested after they were found dead on Wednesday Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: John Kerry 'not discussing' extension for Iran nuclear deadline - video
item.description: The US secretary of state says they are not discussing an extension to high-level negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program. However John Kerry did not completely rule our pushing back the deadline if it became necessary in the closing hours of talks. The aim of talks is to remove sanctions on Tehran in exchange for curbs on Iran's atomic program Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Iraqi Sunnis train to fight Isis militants - video
item.description: Thousands of tribal members from Iraq's Sunni heartland of Anbar train at an army camp in preparation for fighting Isis. Around 1500 men trained at the base in Habaniya, around 85km (50 miles) west of Baghdad. Isis are advancing in Anbar and are coming closer to Baghdad Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Buffalo bears the brunt of heavy snow in New York – in pictures
item.description:
Unseasonally cold weather is gripping the eastern third of the United States. The Buffalo area found itself buried under as much as 5ft (1.5 metres) of snow

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: New York state snowstorm aftermath as seen from a drone – video
item.description: Film-maker James Grimaldi captures the aftermath of a ferocious snow storm that left hundreds of houses under a thick blanket of snow in his home town of West Seneca, Erie County, on Wednesday. Grimaldi recorded the footage with the use of a drone. Another two feet is forecast in Erie County, which includes the city of Buffalo Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Female genital mutilation in Kenya – in pictures
item.description:
About 140 million girls around the world are living with the consequences of FGM. Kenya has banned the practice but it remains prevalent in some communities. Reuters photographer Siegfried Modola gained rare access to a ceremony:

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Isis: we've never seen anything like it, says US defence secretary Chuck Hagel – video
item.description: The US secretary of defence, Chuck Hagel, says dealing with the security threats posed by Islamic State (Isis) is America's top priority. He says that the US has never seen an organisation that is 'so well organised, so well trained, so well funded, so strategic, so brutal, so completely ruthless'. Hagel added that dealing with the Isis threat requires international help Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Revealed: UK ‘mercenaries’ fighting Islamic State terrorist forces in Syria
item.description: Former infantryman James Hughes from Reading, and Jamie Read from Lanarkshire, are said to be in Rojava, northern Syria Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Jamie Read, right, and Jordan Matson in an image posted on Twitter.

item.dc:creator: Mark Townsend

item.title: Finland back on red alert over expansionist Russia
item.description:
Almost a century after breaking free from its giant neighbour Helsinki still follows Moscow’s every move

  • Share your photos and stories of Finland via GuardianWitness
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Simon Tisdall in Helsinki

item.title: Kenya bus attack survivor tells how gunmen selected their victims
item.description:
Al-Shabaab extremists singled out and killed 28 passengers who could not recite Islamic creed, Kenyan police say

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Associated Press in Nairobi

item.title: China building island in South China Sea big enough for military installations
item.description:
The work is visible in satellite images and runs counter to calls from the US for an easing of provocative activity in the much-disputed territory

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Reuters in Washington

item.title: Meet Pirate Joe, the man who (legally) smuggles Trader Joe's goods across the Canadian border
item.description:
For three years Michael Hallatt has been bringing thousands of dollars’ worth of Trader Joe’s products across the border into Vancouver. Our reporter spent a day embedded with Pirate Joe’s ‘cats’ and got an inside look at the cultlike following the pirate brand has captured from the US corporation

  • Pirate Joe’s, the Vancouver store that resells Trader Joe’s goods – in pictures
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch in Bellingham, Washington
